awd_titl_txt: III: Medium: Collaborative Research: KMELIN: Knowledge Mining and Embedding Learning for Complex Dynamic Information Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
Complex dynamic information networks (CDINs) consist of data objects that are highly correlated with a variety of dependency relationships, such as patient-physician interactions or patient-medication-insurance claims. Each data object as a CDIN node has rich contents, such as biometric information of a patient, disease symptoms, or hospital logistics. Data objects and their relationships also continuously evolve and change. Many health, social, physical, and biological systems share the CDIN essence that the multifaceted and dynamic nature of individual nodes imposes significant challenges for modeling a complex and evolving network as a whole. Although data relationships are becoming rich and comprehensive than ever, existing systems are mostly relational-database driven, and cannot integrate complex relationships of networked data for Big Data analytics.

This project aims to design a knowledge mining and embedding learning platform for CDINs that will (1) extract and represent complex structure and rich-content information in the health domain as a CDIN; (2) perform knowledge mining, including clustering and classification, on CDIN networks; (3) enable feature embedding learning with CDINs, so the users can interact with CDINs for content access, and (4) provide a prototype system for hospital re-admission decision support. The spectrum of the methods from the project will not only enrich algorithms and solutions for mining complex structure and rich content networks, as opposed to static networks, but also shift existing health information systems from traditional databases towards becoming network centered systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
1. Enhanced Image Feature Extraction with Cascade Variational Auto-Encoders

This research introduces a novel generative modeling approach utilizing a cascade Variational Auto-Encoder (VAE) framework augmented with a Bayesian network-based regularizer. This regularizer facilitates the discovery of a hierarchical representation space encompassing both disentangled primary features and salient higher-order features, effectively capturing feature interdependencies through the Bayesian structure. Empirical evidence demonstrates that this method enables precise control over the representation space and guides the model towards extracting semantically meaningful, decomposable features. Notably, our approach surpasses state-of-the-art VAE models in balancing synthetic data quality and model interpretability. While developed within the VAE paradigm, this technique exhibits broader applicability, potentially enhancing both Generative Adversarial Networks and VAEs by enabling concurrent optimization of model interpretability and synthesis quality.

2. Mitigating Class Imbalance in Image Classification through Information-Preserving Undersampling

Addressing the pervasive challenge of class imbalance in datasets, particularly in critical applications like medical imaging, this work proposes a novel two-stage undersampling technique. The approach decouples representation learning from rebalancing: initially, robust feature representations are learned from the entire dataset. Subsequently, two innovative undersampling methods (k-DPP-based and a-DPP-based) are employed to selectively sample diverse data from majority classes, effectively balancing the dataset for enhanced classification performance. This strategy significantly reduces information loss inherent in traditional undersampling and mitigates biased decision boundaries, leading to improved classification accuracy across both majority and minority classes. Extensive evaluations demonstrate superior performance compared to existing undersampling, oversampling, re-weighting, and two-stage training methods, along with robust applicability across diverse imbalance ratios and dataset scales.

3. Outlier Detection for Enhanced Content Classification in CDINs

This research addresses the challenge of classifying minority class text descriptions within Content Delivery and Information Networks (CDINs). We developed a novel outlier-based classification approach as follows. Initially, seed corpora are mined for each class to establish reference representations. Leveraging Natural Language Processing techniques, individual words are embedded into a high-dimensional vector space, capturing semantic and syntactic information. A neural network-based word model is then trained, enabling the encoding of text descriptions based on predicted word scores. Subsequently, established outlier detection techniques are applied to these encoded messages, generating outlier scores that facilitate the identification and classification of minority class instances. Empirical results demonstrate the effectiveness of this approach in exposing outlier characteristics, outperforming unsupervised methods and exhibiting competitive performance against supervised approaches.

4. Assessing and Addressing Potential Vulnerabilities in Learning-Based CDIN Systems

Recognizing the inherent vulnerability of learning-based CDIN systems to adversarial attacks, this work presents a novel poisoning attack strategy that operates without prior knowledge of specific algorithms or historical data. By interacting with the target CDIN system and collecting sampled data, a surrogate model is constructed to approximate the system's internal item/content proximity estimations. Attacks are then launched against this surrogate model, with the resulting adversarial solutions directly transferable to the original CDIN system. Extensive experiments across diverse datasets and algorithms validate the effectiveness of this approach. 

5. GAME: GPU-Assisted Memory Expansion for Accelerated Application Execution

This research introduces GAME (GPU-Assisted Memory Expansion), a novel approach to leveraging underutilized GPU memory for enhancing the performance of memory-intensive applications running on the host CPU. By dynamically expanding the CPU's memory capacity onto available GPU DRAM, GAME enables rapid execution of applications with large memory footprints, exceeding the performance of GPU-only execution strategies. Implemented in user space, GAME transparently utilizes GPU memory for swapping memory pages, ensuring high usability and portability without requiring application code modifications. This technique offers significant performance gains for CPU-bound tasks in systems equipped with modern GPUs.

6. Student Training

A total of 8 Ph.D. students and 3 undergraduate students were supported on this project. The Ph.D. students developed foundational knowledge and skill in topics such as graph neural networks, multi-label and heterogeneous gran learning, noise resilience and feature attention. They received training in research guidance and project management, including posing research questions, developing research plans, planning experiments and conducting them. Through regular meetings, they gained experience in communication and collaboration. They were guided in writing research papers and submitting them to conferences and journals, and revising them based on feedback.
